claim_reports.claim_text: Most plastics do not biodegrade and break down into microplastics.
claim_reports.verdict_summary: The evidence strongly supports the claim that most plastics do not biodegrade and instead break down into microplastics. High-reliability sources, such as the PubMed Central article and the University of California report, confirm that plastics persist in the environment for hundreds to thousands of years, ultimately becoming microplastics that contribute to environmental pollution.

supports.title: From plastics to microplastics and organisms - PMC - PubMed Central
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that most plastics do not biodegrade and instead break down into microplastics over time, releasing toxic chemicals into the environment. It emphasizes that plastic does not revert to nature and can persist for hundreds or thousands of years, ultimately becoming microplastics that further pollute ecosystems.
supports.snippet: Plastics are not readily degradable and its biodegradation in natural water bodies takes several years. The process by which plastics biodegrade in the marine ...

supports.title: Say hello to biodegradable microplastics | University of California
supports.evidence_summary: The article confirms that most plastics do not biodegrade and instead break down into microplastics, which persist in the environment and can release toxic chemicals. It emphasizes that plastic does not revert to nature and highlights the environmental issues caused by plastic waste.
supports.snippet: New research from scientists at the University of California San Diego and materials-science company Algenesis shows that their plant-based polymers biodegrade.

supports.title: The plastic crisis: What's the big deal with microplastics?
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that plastic waste does not biodegrade but instead breaks down into smaller pieces, known as microplastics, due to environmental factors like wind and sunlight.
supports.snippet: Plastic waste does not biodegrade, rather, it breaks down, fragmented by wind, waves, and sunlight into ever-smaller pieces. The two main ...

unclear.evidence_summary: Discarded improperly, plastic waste pollutes and harms the environment, becoming a widespread driver of biodiversity loss and ecosystem degradation.
unclear.snippet: Discarded improperly, plastic waste pollutes and harms the environment, becoming a widespread driver of biodiversity loss and ecosystem degradation.

supports.snippet: Microplastics accounted for 8% of the total mass but 94% of the estimated 1.8 (1.1–3.6) trillion pieces floating in the area. Plastic collected ...

claim_reports.claim_text: Animals mistake plastic for food, leading to starvation and toxin transfer up the food chain.
claim_reports.verdict_summary: The evidence strongly supports the claim that animals mistake plastic for food, leading to starvation and toxin transfer up the food chain. Multiple high-reliability sources confirm that ingestion of plastic can block the digestive system, causing animals to feel full and reducing their urge to eat, which results in starvation. This is corroborated by studies from ScienceDirect, Mongabay, and PubMed.

supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that animals mistake plastic for food, leading to serious health issues such as starvation and toxin transfer up the food chain. Specifically, it states that ingestion of plastic can block the digestive system, making animals feel full and reducing their urge to eat, which can result in starvation.

claim_reports.claim_text: Leachate is a harmful stew created when rainwater absorbs toxic compounds from compressed waste.
claim_reports.verdict_summary: The evidence strongly supports the claim that leachate is a harmful stew created when rainwater absorbs toxic compounds from compressed waste. Multiple high-reliability sources, including the U.S. Geological Survey and NIH, confirm that leachate is formed through the percolation of liquid through waste, extracting harmful substances and posing significant health risks.

supports.title: EarthWord – Leachate | U.S. Geological Survey - USGS.gov
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that leachate is formed when liquid, such as rainwater, passes through waste and extracts harmful substances, thus supporting the claim that leachate is a harmful stew created from toxic compounds in compressed waste.
supports.snippet: Leachate is the solution (or suspension) that forms when liquid travels through a solid and removes some components of that solid with it.

supports.title: Impact of landfill leachate contamination on surface and ... - NIH
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that leachate is a toxic byproduct generated from landfills, which can contaminate groundwater and surface water, posing significant health risks due to the presence of heavy metals and other harmful compounds.
supports.snippet: If this fresh leachate can percolate to the groundwater system or overflowed to the surface water, it may exert high toxic effect on aquatic ...

supports.title: FAQs • What is leachate? How is it controlled? - SPSA
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that leachate is produced when rainwater percolates through waste, extracting harmful substances, thus supporting the claim that leachate is a harmful stew created from toxic compounds in compressed waste.
supports.snippet: Leachate is the liquid that drains from a landfill or through waste materials and has extracted some component of the material through which it has passed. The ...

supports.title: Landfill leachate: Sources, nature, organic composition, and treatment
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that leachate is generated when precipitation percolates through waste in landfills, absorbing harmful substances, which aligns with the claim that leachate is a harmful stew created from toxic compounds in compressed waste.
supports.snippet: Principally, the leachate is generated due to the water-precipitation percolating through waste deposition in a landfill. Once such precipitation is in contact ...

supports.title: Leachate: Understanding Its Threat to Water Quality - G3SoilWorks
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that leachate is a toxic byproduct generated from landfills, which can percolate into groundwater and surface water, posing significant risks to water quality and public health.
supports.snippet: Leachate is a liquid pollutant that forms when water interacts with waste materials, carrying contaminants that seriously threaten water quality.

claim_reports.claim_text: Plastic bottles are made by chemically bonding oil and gas molecules to create monomers.
claim_reports.verdict_summary: The evidence strongly supports the claim that plastic bottles are made by chemically bonding oil and gas molecules to create monomers. Multiple reliable sources, including the Live Science article and Plastics Europe, explain that plastics, specifically polyethylene terephthalate (PET), are produced from monomers derived from crude oil and natural gas.

supports.title: How do we turn oil into plastic? - Live Science
supports.evidence_summary: The article explains that plastics are produced from hydrocarbons derived from oil and natural gas, which are broken down into their component parts to create monomers used in plastic production. This supports the claim that plastic bottles are made by chemically bonding oil and gas molecules to create monomers.
supports.snippet: Plastic that's synthesized from oil and natural gas is made by isolating hydrocarbons, breaking them down into their component parts and then ...

supports.title: How Are Plastic Bottles Made? | The Cary Company
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence explains that plastic bottles are made from polyethylene terephthalate (PET), which is produced by chemically combining two monomers derived from crude oil, specifically monoethylene glycol (MEG) and dimethyl terephthalate (DMT). This process confirms the claim that plastic bottles are made by chemically bonding oil and gas molecules to create monomers.
supports.snippet: The Bottle-Making Process · 1. Plastic Resin Preparation & Melting · 2. Bottle Forming Methods · 3. Cooling & Trimming · 4. The Inspection Process.

supports.evidence_summary: The article explains that plastics, including plastic bottles, are made from feedstocks derived from natural gas and crude oil, which are processed into basic building blocks for plastics. This supports the claim that oil and gas molecules are chemically bonded to create monomers, as these feedstocks are essential in the production process.

supports.evidence_summary: The evidence explains that plastic bottles are made from crude oil, which is refined into naphtha, and then two monomers (monoethylene glycol and dimethyl terephthalate) are chemically combined to create the polymer PET. This supports the claim that plastic bottles are made by chemically bonding oil and gas molecules to create monomers.
supports.snippet: Plastics are made from natural materials such as cellulose, coal, natural gas, salt and crude oil through a polymerisation or polycondensation process.

The reliability of the sources is medium, leading to an unclear overall stance.

transcript_data.text: This is the story of three plastic bottles, empty and discarded. Their journeys are about to diverge with outcomes that impact nothing less than the fate of the planet. But they weren't always this way. To understand where these bottles end up, we must first explore their origins. The heroes of our story were conceived in this oil refinery. The plastic in their bodies was formed by chemically bonding oil and gas molecules together to make monomers. In turn, these monomers were bonded into long polymer chains to make plastic in the form of millions of pellets. Those were melted at manufacturing plants and reformed in molds to create the resilient material that makes up the triplets' bodies. Machines filled the bottles with sweet bubbily liquid and they were then wrapped, shipped, bought, opened, consumed and unceremoniously discarded. And now here they lie, poised at the edge of the unknown. Bottle one, like hundreds of millions of tons of his plastic brethren, ends up in a landfill. This huge dump expands each day as more trash comes in and continues to take up space. As plastics sit there being compressed amongst layers of other junk, rainwater flows through the waste and absorbs the water-soluble compounds it contains, and some of those are highly toxic. Together, they create a harmful stew called leachate, which can move into groundwater, soil and streams, poisoning ecosystems and harming wildlife. It can take bottle one an agonizing 1,000 years to decompose. Bottle two's journey is stranger but, unfortunately, no happier. He floats on a trickle that reaches a stream, a stream that flows into a river, and a river that reaches the ocean. After months lost at sea, he's slowly drawn into a massive vortex, where trash accumulates, a place known as the Great Pacific Garbage Patch. Here the ocean's currents have trapped millions of pieces of plastic debris. This is one of five plastic-filled gyres in the world's seas. Places where the pollutants turn the water into a cloudy plastic soup. Some animals, like seabirds, get entangled in the mess. They, and others, mistake the brightly colored plastic bits for food. Plastic makes them feel full when they're not, so they starve to death and pass the toxins from the plastic up the food chain. For example, it's eaten by lanternfish, the lanternfish are eaten by squid, the squid are eaten by tuna, and the tuna are eaten by us. And most plastics don't biodegrade, which means they're destined to break down into smaller and smaller pieces called micro plastics, which might rotate in the sea eternally. But bottle three is spared the cruel purgatories of his brothers. A truck brings him to a plant where he and his companions are squeezed flat and compressed into a block. Okay, this sounds pretty bad, too, but hang in there. It gets better. The blocks are shredded into tiny pieces, which are washed and melted, so they become the raw materials that can be used again. As if by magic, bottle three is now ready to be reborn as something completely new. For this bit of plastic with such humble origins, suddenly the sky is the limit.

segments.text:
This is the story 
of three plastic bottles,
empty and discarded.
Their journeys are about to diverge

with outcomes that impact nothing less
than the fate of the planet.
But they weren't always this way.

To understand where these bottles end up,
we must first explore their origins.

The heroes of our story
were conceived in this oil refinery.
The plastic in their bodies

was formed by chemically bonding 
oil and gas molecules together
to make monomers.

In turn, these monomers were bonded
into long polymer chains to make plastic
in the form of millions of pellets.

Those were melted at manufacturing plants
and reformed in molds

to create the resilient material
that makes up the triplets' bodies.

Machines filled the bottles
with sweet bubbily liquid

and they were then wrapped, shipped,
bought, opened, consumed
and unceremoniously discarded.
And now here they lie,
poised at the edge of the unknown.

Bottle one, like hundreds of millions
of tons of his plastic brethren,
ends up in a landfill.
This huge dump expands each day

as more trash comes in
and continues to take up space.

As plastics sit there being compressed
amongst layers of other junk,
rainwater flows through the waste

and absorbs the water-soluble 
compounds it contains,
and some of those are highly toxic.

Together, they create a harmful stew
called leachate,

which can move into groundwater, 
soil and streams,
poisoning ecosystems and harming wildlife.

It can take bottle one an agonizing
1,000 years to decompose.

Bottle two's journey is stranger
but, unfortunately, no happier.

He floats on a trickle 
that reaches a stream,
a stream that flows into a river,
and a river that reaches the ocean.
After months lost at sea,

he's slowly drawn into a massive vortex,
where trash accumulates,

a place known as 
the Great Pacific Garbage Patch.

Here the ocean's currents have trapped
millions of pieces of plastic debris.

This is one of five plastic-filled
gyres in the world's seas.

Places where the pollutants
turn the water into a cloudy plastic soup.

Some animals, like seabirds, 
get entangled in the mess.

They, and others, mistake the brightly
colored plastic bits for food.

Plastic makes them feel full 
when they're not,
so they starve to death

and pass the toxins from the plastic
up the food chain.
For example, it's eaten by lanternfish,
the lanternfish are eaten by squid,
the squid are eaten by tuna,
and the tuna are eaten by us.
And most plastics don't biodegrade,

which means they're destined to break down
into smaller and smaller pieces
called micro plastics,
which might rotate in the sea eternally.

But bottle three is spared the cruel
purgatories of his brothers.
A truck brings him to a plant

where he and his companions 
are squeezed flat
and compressed into a block.

Okay, this sounds pretty bad, too,
but hang in there.
It gets better.

The blocks are shredded
into tiny pieces,
which are washed and melted,

so they become the raw materials
that can be used again.

As if by magic, bottle three
is now ready to be reborn
as something completely new.

For this bit of plastic
with such humble origins,
suddenly the sky is the limit.
